description.narrative:
Detta beslut är ett kompletterande insatsbeslut till avtal med OCHA om bidrag till humanitära insatser, och gäller år 2017. Avtalsperioden förlängdes i januari 2016 till 30 oktober 2018 i syfte att säkerställa att det sammanfaller med OCHA:s strategi (Strategic Framework) för 2014 - 2017.
Huvudsyftet med insatsen är att stödja OCHA i sitt uppdrag att implementera sitt samordningsmandat stipulerat i Resolution 46/182. Detta mandat konkretiseras vidare genom "OCHA Plan and Budget 2016". Huvudsyftet med stödet är att stödja Mål 1 "Field Effectivenes", med följande delmål: 1. Stärkt humanitärt ledarskap 2. Harmonisering och koordinering av behovsbedömningar 3. Gemensam humanitär responsplanering, implementering och uppföljning 4. Flxibel och anpassningsbara koordineringsstrukturer 5. Skydd för och tillträde till drabbade befolkning
År 2017 tilldelas OCHA:s landkontor, regionala kontor samt tekniska program sammanlagt 100 MSK (varav detta beslut avser 4 MSK) med följande fördelning:
För landkontor sammanlagt 78 MSEK: Afghanistan 3,5 MSEK, CAR 4 MSEK, DRK 7 MSEK, Irak 3 MSEK, Mali 4 MSEK, Niger 4 MSEK, Tchad 4 MSEK, Kamerun 4 MSEK, Palestina 2 MSEK, Somalia 4 MSEK, Sydsudan 5 MSEK, Sudan 2 MSEK, Jemen 5 MSEK, Colombia 1 MSEK, Etiopien 2 MSEK, Myanmar 2 MSEK, Pakistan 2 MSEK, Syrienkrisen (inkl. kontoren Syrien, Turkiet, Jordanien, Libanon) 10 MSEK, Philippines 1 MSEK, Ukraina 1,5 MSEK, Haiti 1 MSEK, Nigeria 4 MSEK, Libyen 1 MSEK, Burundi 1 MSEK.
För regionala kontor sammanlagt 13 MSEK: Västra Afrika 4 MSK, Östra Afrika 2 MSK, Mellanöstern och Norra Afrika 2 MSK, Asien 4 MSK, Stilla havet 1 MSEK.
För tekniska program sammanlagt 9 MSEK: GenCap 4 MSK, ProCap 3 MSK, and UNDAC 2 MSK.
Sverige är OCHA:s tredje största givare (efter USA och Storbritannien). Sidas stöd kompletterar UD:s kärnstöd, vars nivå i 2017 beslutas av regeringen. Ifjol var kärnstödet 125 MSEK. I 2016 gav UD dessutom ett extra tillägg på 70 MSEK, som öronmärktes till fältkontoren. Sidas stöd kompletterar kärnstödet genom att det tilldelas på basis av behov i respektive kris och ändras därmed från år till år baserat på behoven som fastställs i december varje år (genom Humanitarian Needs Overview och Humanitarian Response Plan). Det initiala stödet för 2017 kan komma att kompletteras genom ett eller flera tilläggsbeslut under året som en följd av Sidas bedömning av ökade humanitära behov eller underfinansiering i specifika kontexter.

Sida has already in 2016 decided and agreed on SEK 96,000,000 for 2017. Through this decision, a supplement of SEK 4,000,000 is made, which means a total financing of SEK 100,000,000 for 2017. Also the distribution of the support between country and regional offices as well as technical programs are made through this supplementary intervention decision and attached contract supplement.
The main purpose of the initiative is to support OCHA in its mission to implement its coordination mandate stipulated in Resolution 46/182. This mandate is further concretized through "OCHA Plan and Budget 2016". The main purpose of the support is to support Objective 1 "Field Effectivenes", with the following sub-objectives: Strengthened humanitarian leadership
In 2017, OCHA's country offices, regional offices and technical programs will be allocated a total of SEK 100 million (of which this decision pertains to SEK 4 million) with the following distribution: For country offices a total of SEK 78 million: Afghanistan SEK 3.5 million, CAR SEK 4 million, DRK SEK 7 million, Iraq SEK 3 million, Mali SEK 4 million, Niger SEK 4 million, Chad SEK 4 million, Cameroon SEK 4 million, Palestine SEK 2 million, Somalia SEK 4 million, South Sudan 5 MSEK, Sudan 2 MSEK, Yemen 5 MSEK, Colombia 2 MSEK, Ethiopia 2 MSEK, Myanmar 2 MSEK, Pakistan 2 MSEK, Syria crisis (incl. Offices Syria, Turkey, Jordan, Lebanon) 10 MSEK, Philippines 1 MSEK, Ukraine 1.5 MSEK MSEK, Haiti 1 MSEK, Nigeria 4 MSEK, Libya 1 MSEK, Burundi 1 MSEK. For regional offices a total of SEK 13 million: West Africa 4 million, East Africa 2 million, Middle East and North Africa 2 million, Asia 4 million, Pacific 1 million. For technical programs a total of SEK 9 million: GenCap 4 million, ProCap 3 million, and UNDAC 2 million. The above distribution is based on Sida's needs-based humanitarian allocation model.
Sweden is OCHA's third largest donor (after the USA and the UK). Sida's support complements the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' core support, the level of which in 2017 will be decided by the government. Last year, the core support was SEK 125 million. In 2016, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs also gave an extra supplement of SEK 70 million, which was earmarked for the field offices. Sida's support complements the core support by allocating it on the basis of needs in each crisis and thus changing from year to year based on the needs determined in December each year (through the Humanitarian Needs Overview and Humanitarian Response Plan). The initial support for 2017 may be supplemented by one or more additional decisions during the year as a result of Sida's assessment of increased humanitarian needs or underfunding in specific contexts.

UN OCHA is the part of the United Nations Secretariat responsible for bringing together humanitarian actors to ensure a coherent response to emergencies. OCHA also ensures there is a framework within which each actor can contribute to the overall response effort. OCHA’s mandate stems from General Assembly (GA) resolution 46/182 of December 1991, which states: “The leadership role of the Secretary-General is critical and must be strengthened to ensure better preparation for, as well as rapid and coherent response to, natural disasters and other emergencies.” To this end, it also establishes the role of the Emergency Relief Coordinator (ERC), who works with the Secretary-General and the Inter-Agency Standing Committee (IASC) in leading, coordinating and facilitating humanitarian assistance. OCHA is the office that provides support to the ERC and the Secretary-General to meet the leadership and coordination responsibilities charted in GA resolution 46/182. OCHAs vision is that: 1) People are better able to withstand shocks, 2) Governments are aware of risks, are well prepared and able to respond to disasters quickly and effectively and 3) International assistance is provided quickly, efficiently and appropriately. Between 2014 and 2017, OCHA has worked towards this vision in two ways: First, it recognizes the importance of continuing to provide strategic humanitarian leadership and coordination to meet the needs of affected people by the implementation of the IASC Transformative Agenda, and by building strong, flexible coordination mechanisms. Second, OCHA will respond to the changes in the humanitarian sector by fostering a spirit of innovation. It will analyze trends, anticipate change and identify new forms of action with a wide range of providers and partners. Based on the above and in line with its mandate, OCHA has two goals for 2014 to 2017 underpinned by 10 strategic objectives. These define the focus of OCHA’s work in the field and at headquarters, as well as the overarching priorities towards which all of its activities contribute. Goal 1 "Field Efficiency" and its 7 Strategic Outcomes: 1. Leadership - Humanitarian Action is led by empowered, competent and experienced professionals. 2. Situational Awareness - Humanitarian decisions making is based on a common situational awareness. 3. Assessment, Planning and Monitoring - Humanitarian action is guided by joint strategic planning based on prioritised needs. 4. Coordination Mechanisms - Coordination mechanisms are adapted to the context and support the effective and coherent delivery of humanitarian assistance. 5. Protection and Access to Assistance - People in emergencies are protected from harm and have access to the assistance as a result of advocacy and coordination. 6. Humanitarian Financing - Humanitarian financing is predictable, timely and allocated based on priority needs. 7. Emergency response preparedness -International partners are ready to respond to humanitarian emergencies without delay and with the right assistance. Goal 2 “Fit for the future” and its 3 strategic outcomes: 1. Diversity - A more diverse set of actors engages in and provides political, technical and material support to collective humanitarian action. 2. Interoperability - International, regional and national actors are able to deploy well-coordinated and interoperable humanitarian response capacities within agreed frameworks. 3. Innovation - Innovation to promote improvement is consistently fostered and brought to scale in the humanitarian sector. Goal 1 is in line with Sweden’s priorities in the “Swedish Strategy for Humanitarian Assistance 2017-2020” and has therefore been assessed to be of strategic relevance for Sidas engagement with OCHA during the agreement period.

description.narrative: From the previous four-year agreement with OCHA and the Strategic Plan and results reporting 2014-17, evidence shows that OCHA has the ability to work systematically to meet set objectives. On most indicators in the results framework, OCHA has shown progress according to plan. From Sida’s perspective two areas of OCHA’s work – its efforts on joint assessment and planning and work on humanitarian access – merit particular mention here. Sida assesses these functions as key to OCHA’s value added in humanitarian responses. a) Developing the Humanitarian Programme Cycle OCHA’s efforts in applying and developing the humanitarian needs overviews (HNOs) and response plans (HRPs), has led to improved prioritization of needs. HNOs and HRPs are receiving better quality scores (according to OCHA’s internal rating system). All HRPs produced received a high-quality score in 2016 (target 80%), and 88% of HCTs produced a high-quality joint needs assessment (up from 43% in 2014). Partner surveys also show that in all countries with an HRP, at least half of partners say they base their planning and programming on the HRP. While more work certainly remains in improving the HRPs, Sida has noted a movement towards better prioritized HRPs in many contexts, meaning soem HRPs have been reduced to include only prioritized life-saving activities and projects (e.g. Afghanistan, Iraq). Sida notes that contexts that are particularly conducive to well-prioritized HRPs often include a strong RC/HC that leads the process of reducing the appeal and joint planning with the development side. OCHA has also made progress in introducing models for multi-year response planning in protracted crises. The response plans are a particularly important tool for Sida’s own allocation model. Sida contributes to strengthening joint response planning by ensuring that its funding to UN and NGO partners is within the response plans. Data from OCHA’s Financial Tracking System (FTS) shows that some 90% of Sida’s funding in 2017 is within the plans, where such exist. b) Enhancing access and protection through advocacy and negotiations OCHA's role in access monitoring and advocacy has continued to grow in relevance as crises increase in complexity, not least in countries like Somalia, South-Sudan, Syria, Afghanistan, and other conflict-ridden countries. OCHA has led both global and in country humanitarian advocacy efforts. Achievements on the country level include, for example, OCHA’s work in Afghanistan where the OCHA-coordinated Access Working Group’s negotiations with the military resulted in the removal of 85% of access limitations. In Syria (Damascus), the OCHA office has held the extremely complex and central task of negotiating, planning and deploying of inter-agency convoys into besieged areas, which has contributed to an increase in assistance to hard-to-reach areas. In 2017, the Turkey offices worked hard to negotiate access to humanitarian organizations. The work of OCHA resulted in an ”Access Letter”, which functions as a contract with mutual obligations between humanitarian organisations and armed groups in Northern Syria. In many contexts, equally important has been OCHA’s promotion of ‘humanitarian space’ through negotiations with governments on e.g. registration of NGOs or visas for humanitarian staff. These are all examples of where OCHA has had a unique value added as a non-operational facilitator, a role which no other actor can easily take on. There are also several examples of how OCHA’s efforts and leverage on the global level has created significant, life-saving results at the country level. The Emergency Relief Coordinator's briefings (28 in 2016) to the Security Council has continued as one of OCHA's most important vehicles for this. OCHA's contributions to UN Security Council resolutions on cross-border access in the Syria crisis have made it possible to significantly scale up life-saving assistance to the most affected areas of Syria. Key results during 2014-2017 in other areas include, for example: - Through OCHA:s support to HCs and HCTs, humanitarian leadership is improving. - 75% of in-country partners are satisfied with the HC and HCT leadership (on target). - Information management has been further improved. The percentage of field offices receiving a high score for core information management products has gone from 71 to 88% (target 80%). - While the global policy function is not a major focus of this appraisal, it should be mentioned that OCHA had a central role in the preparations for the organisation and substance of the World Humanitarian Summit in 2016. The most visible result of the WHS are the Grand Bargain commitments, a policy framework for a more effective humanitarian response. - OCHA’s advocacy strategy, in coordination with partners, focused on ways to improve humanitarian access. This resulted in the passing of UN Security Council resolutions 2139 and 2165, which enabled access across conflict lines and borders without the Syrian Government’s agreement. - OCHA provided strong advocacy support on access at all levels. It stepped up its work with actors outside formal Whole of Syria (WoS) coordination arrangements to increase common understanding of the situation in locations seized by designated terrorist groups. - OCHA actively contributed to the development and dissemination of an IASC protection policy. It worked with the Global Protection Cluster to create practical guidance on integrating standards on protection, access and displacement in an HCT protection strategy. - OCHA mobilized funding and lobbied for improved access to people caught up in protracted crises in the Central African Republic (CAR), the Lake Chad Basin, Syria, Yemen and beyond. In Syria, despite access challenges in reaching besieged and hard-to-reach areas, UN assistance reached millions of people each month. In Yemen, the site of the world’s worst food security crisis, OCHA mobilized resources and advocated constantly for humanitarian access, including the lifting of a blockade by the Saudi-led coalition towards the end of the year. Challenges There are however also areas where evidence indicates that OCHA has some difficulty in creating progress. One such area relates to the difficulty of creating consistent buy-in from humanitarian organisations on the ground. The partner survey shows that OCHA has not been able to increase the overall satisfaction among its 'clients', the humanitarian organizations on the ground, during the past strategy period. In about 20 percent of countries, less than half of the partners are satisfied with OCHA's support to enhance the effectiveness of coordination mechanisms. While the result certainly merits further discussion, Sida assesses that part of the challenge can be linked to the nature of services that OCHA provides. Among partners on the country-level, coordination is sometimes perceived as an extra layer or work which is ‘imposed’ on them. At the same time, OCHA (and currently even the HC) has no formal authority over the organisations. Competition and mandate issues within the UN system may also be part of the dynamics. Sida’s field experiences and dialogue (e.g. with the NGO network ICVA) indicate that appreciation of OCHA’s services is often higher within the NGO community than within the UN family. Keeping UN agencies accountable to their commitments to coordination is a larger UN system issue that Sweden/Sida should continue to follow and engage in. Moreover, results reporting indicates more attention is needed on adjusting coordination structures to changing contexts. This is an area that is a priority for OCHA going forward and efforts are now being put on encouraging and developing appropriate methods for context adjustment. Effectively moving away from one-model-fit- all towards a promotion of locally adapted coordination mechanisms may also have a positive effect on the above mentioned challenge around partner satisfaction. GenCAp and ProCAP Concerning GenCap and ProCap, an analysis of end-of mission reports (by the Support Unit) presents some key results from 2016-17 showing that projects have contributed to gender equality programming and protection are now better embedded in humanitarian tools and processes and integrated across the operational response. For example, in many contexts gender coordination mechanisms have been established and the accountability of the humanitarian system for gender equality programming is strengthened through the application of the Gender Markers. As an example, during 2016 and 2017 the GenCap advisor in Sudan supported the HCT to incorporate a sustainable approach to gender equality programming and contributed to the HCT Gender Commitments as well as helped establishing a gender task force, supported two CBPF projects, and developed gender guidance for the humanitarian programme cycle. In Yemen, GenCap helped building the capacity of national gender trainers through trainings and mentoring, and trained cluster partners in gender sensitive project design and monitoring. A lack of systematic M&E beyond the input and output levels makes it challenging to establish the longer-term outcomes of deployments. The Independent Strategic Review of GenCap and ProCap in 2017 confirmed that the projects remain relevant and should be retained at least until the end of 2021. The review did however not have an evaluative approach and hence it did not significantly contribute to understanding the effectiveness of the projects.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
